Dear Ms. O’Neill:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Special evaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327
Section (1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to possible
Description noncompliance with any foster home rule, the agency must do all
the following:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner prescribed
by the department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency allowed a foster child to use a basement bedroom
that is unfinished. It was aware of the foster home's
noncompliance with the rule related the bedroom and allowed it to
continue. It did not alert the department. A variance request was in
progress but has not been submitted or approved.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant
On 10/10/2024 I spoke with Complainant, and she confirmed the
allegations. She reported the child is in a basement bedroom with
partial walls and that the area is under construction. She reported
the foster parent reported they had a variance in place, but per
CWLM, the agency started a variance in late August 2024, when
the child was placed, but never submitted that variance.
Complainant said the agency started the variance again after
August but have not followed-up on it.
Chief Administrator
On 10/11/2024 I spoke with Chief Administrator (CA) about this
allegation by telephone. CA reported the foster family had been
working on putting in a bedroom in the basement, so that any child
placed in their home would not have to share a room with the
couple’s son. CA reported prior to completion of the construction
on the bedroom, the agency received a referral on 17-year-old
male, and the couple did now want this youth to share a bedroom
with the foster parent’s son. Therefore, they pursued this youth’s
placement in the basement bedroom, that was nice, but since it
did not meet licensing requirements the agency sought a variance.
CA reported she was told a variance was completed by the
licensing worker and it was approval. She indicated that would
have been why no special evaluation record for any possible rule
violations would not have been submitted. She reported she was
2

following up on this matter and I could speak with the licensing
worker and licensing supervisor for more information.
Licensing Worker
On 11/4/2024 I interviewed Licensing Worker (LW) by telephone.
LW admitted Youth A was occupying a basement bedroom in
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2’s home which did not meet
licensing requirements. She reported Foster Parent 1 thought he
could get the work on the basement bedroom completed over the
weekend before Youth A was placed but Foster Parent 1 did not
complete the work. She said, then the agency thought they could
get a variance completed before Youth A’s 8/22/2024 placement
date. LW admitted Youth A’s placement was not an emergency
placement. She admitted she nor anyone to her knowledge had
communication with DCWL (Division of Child Welfare Licensing)
about the agency’s placement situation related to Youth A and a
need for a timely variance.
LW could not answer as to whether she knew the foster home’s
bedroom construction was not completed prior to the Youth A’s
placement in the foster home. She reported to her knowledge the
foster care unit was not aware there was a placement issue. Nor
did she advise foster care there was one. She stated” We
probably dropped the ball on that”. She also did not know if her
supervisor was aware that there was a foster home bedroom
issue. She reported she was told after the fact that Youth A's
placement in the foster home had occurred.
LW reported that she is new to licensing. She reported that Youth
A’s placement in the foster home did not remind her of the need to
complete the variance. It was the foster family’s renewal coming
due that did so. She said she had to go to the home and at the
time she saw the bedroom construction was incomplete. She
admitted the matter of the variance came up during her
supervision with Licensing Supervisor, but she could not recall if
that was in August or September of this year. She said they had
discussed the need for the variance on the foster home earlier, but
afterward they both got busy and forgot about it. She denied
telling the foster family that a variance was approved. She told
them she had to get one approved. She acknowledged it was her
responsibility to complete the variance. She initiated the variance
again on 10/4/2024 and it was subsequently submitted and
approved by DCWL.
Licensing Supervisor
3

On 11/4/2024 I interviewed Licensing Supervisor (LS) by
telephone. LS reported this allegation matter was discovered
during a DCWL Analyst review. She said the DCWL Analyst told
them they did not have to open a special evaluation, that they just
needed to complete a variance. LS reported “We just dropped the
ball and never finished the variance”.
LS admitted to knowing there was an issue with the foster family
basement bedroom prior to Youth A’s placement. She said Foster
Parent 1 had told the agency he would have the work on the
basement walls and ceiling done in 30 days, but Foster Parent 1
did not complete the work in that timeframe.
LS was not aware of anyone telling the foster family that a
variance was already approved. Nor had the agency contacted
DCWL before Youth A’s 8/22/2024 placement about an expedited
variance. Though, LS reported that once they submitted the
variance to DCWL it was approved in one day.
Foster Parent 1
On 11/4/2024 I interviewed Foster Parent 1 by telephone. Foster
Parent 1 reported not knowing whether he told the agency he
would have the ceiling work done on the basement bedroom
before they got a placement. He reported he and Foster Parent 2
were told the agency was going to write a variance so that Youth
A could get placed in their home. Foster Parent 1 could not recall
whether he was told the variance would eliminate them having to
complete the remodeling/ceiling work on the bedroom. Nor did he
know if they were told the variance was approved before Youth
A’s placement. He said he did not know the bedroom was still a
problem until the DCWL Analyst was out inspecting their home.
He reported that there is a variance in place now. He said as to
the variance approval before now, he thinks the worker forgot
about the variance needing to be completed.
Reviewed
Safety Alert for Foster Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s home
dated 10/10/2024 which indicated:
• Foster child’s bedroom does not have finished floor to
ceiling walls. Nor a painted/sealed/finished ceiling.
• Wellspring’s resolution response indicated they were
advised by the DCWL Analyst that no special evaluation is
needed. That a three month’s variance to the rule was
being requested. To bring the bedroom into compliance a
FIG grant request was being submitted to assist the foster
4

parents in covering part of the financial cost to complete the
drop ceiling.
Documents from LS showed:
• The agency submitted for a FIG grant on 10/23/2024 and
received subsequent approval.
• A photo showing the non- finished wall and incomplete
ceiling of the bedroom in question.
• A variance approval on 10/30/2024 by the DCWL Director.
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2’s CWLM file showed:
• The couple were licensed in May 2023.
• Youth A was placed in the foster home on 8/22/2024. He is
the only youth documented as placed in the foster home.
• A variance was submitted by LS related to the home on
10/23/2024. This variance was approval by the DCWL
director on 10/30/2024.
• Documentation listed above as provided by LS.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed, the agency is in
violation of this rule. The agency did not submit a special
investigation record to the department within the required
timeframe related to the foster parent’s basement bedroom which
did not meet foster home licensing rule requirements. The agency
intended to complete a variance to address this issue but did not
timely follow up on that submission prior to the youth’s placement
in the home and the youth’s occupancy of the non-compliant
bedroom.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current licensing status is recommended.
